questions.question_text:
You have a computer that runs Windows 10 and contains a user named User1 and the following local Group Policy Objects (GPOs):

• Local Computer Policy
• Local Computer\User1 Policy
• Local Computer\Administrators Policy
• Local Computer\Non-Administrators Policy

You need to ensure that User1 must use a password that is at least 10 characters.

Which GPO should you modify?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The Password policy option is not available for a User since it's a computer policy. I've tested this myself. Within the " Local Computer\User1" policy there is no way to set a password policy.

So the correct answer is: A

Selected Answer: D
D is the correct Awnser, the question only wants User1 to use 10 characters password, the others remains unchanged.

Selected Answer: A
A

It is available at LGPO > Computer Configuration > Windows Settings > Account Policies > Password Policies > Minimum password length policy

Remember that Computer Configuration is only available through LGPO.

comments.content: Tested, I think A is right

discussion.content: The correct GPO to modify in this scenario is "Local Computer Policy". This GPO affects all users on the local computer, so modifying it would ensure that the password policy for User1, as well as all other users, meets the requirement of being at least 10 characters. "Local Computer\User1 Policy" only affects the User1 user account, while "Local Computer\Administrators Policy" and "Local Computer\Non-Administrators Policy" only affect administrators and non-administrators, respectively.

A. Quick Assist is the tool that meets the requirements.
Quick Assist is a built-in Windows 10 tool that allows you to remotely assist another person with their computer. It's designed to be a quick and easy solution for help desk administrators to connect to a user's computer and perform troubleshooting without disrupting the user's desktop. Quick Assist allows you to remotely view services, performance counters, registry settings, and event logs, making it a great choice for your scenario.
While Intune does offer remote management capabilities for devices enrolled in its management platform, it is not specifically designed for the use case of remote assistance and troubleshooting. Intune primarily focuses on managing device settings and security policies, rather than providing a direct remote connection to the user's desktop.
For the specific requirements listed, Quick Assist is the better choice as it provides a more direct and focused solution for remote assistance and troubleshooting. While Intune can be used to remotely access devices, it may not offer the same level of granular control and visibility into the user's desktop as Quick Assist.

questions.question_text:
You have 100 computers that run Windows 10. The computers are joined to an Azure AD tenant and enrolled in Microsoft Intune. The computers are in remote locations and connected to public networks.

You need to recommend a solution for help desk administrators that meets the following requirements:

• Connect remotely to a user's computer to perform troubleshooting.
• Connect to a user's computer without disrupting the desktop of the computer.
• Remotely view services, performance counters, registry settings, and event logs.

Which tool should you include in the recommendation?

discussion.content:
C. Enable the File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request - ICMPv4-In) inbound rule.

Enabling the "File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request - ICMPv4-In)" inbound rule allows the computer to respond to ICMPv4 echo requests, which are used by the ping command to validate network connectivity. This rule is disabled by default in Windows Defender Firewall, so it needs to be enabled to allow the ping command to work.

choices.B: Create a new connection security rule.
choices.A: Enable the Core Networking - Teredo (UDP-In) inbound rule.
choices.C: Enable the File and Printer Sharing (Echo Request - ICMPv4-In) inbound rule.
choices.D: Add a new port rule to allow ports 80 and 443.

questions.question_text:
You have a computer named Computer1 that runs Windows 11.

You need to ensure that you can use the ping command to validate network connectivity to Computer1.

How should you configure Windows Defender Firewall on Computer1?

choices.A: Add User1 to the local Administrators group.
choices.C: Run RSoP from an elevated-privilege account.
choices.D: Add User1 to the local Performance Monitor Users group.
choices.B: Add User2 to the local Performance Monitor Users group.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Administrator have this permission. Other roles don't.

Selected Answer: A
I'll vote A.
Maybe not the best of sources, but I found this: https://social.technet.microsoft.com/Forums/windows/en-US/33f021ba-66ca-466c-a44f-2393f8c607db/view-rsop-data-for-logged-on-user-that-is-not-administrator?forum=w7itprosecurity
In my environment i have a normal and admin accounts, so option C is great for admins. Question ask how User1 gets access, and that will require Administrator rights.

comments.content: Note that the UAC screen allows User1, using its own credential, to access the RSoP Wizard, but all that User1 can see is in the question statement image. In order for User1 to gain access to the specific user User2, he will have to log in with administrator privileges.

This question is a little bit tricky.

I don't know what is less worse in this case. One scenario would be some administrator loggin in with that administrator privilege or giving User1 the administrator privilege (which would be the A answer).

But I will stick with C.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C. Run RSoP from an elevated-privilege account.

RSoP is available through mmc. User1 being part of Performance Monitor Users or Power Users does not allow access to the mmc. So the best choice considering the principle is to elevate privileges temporarily.

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT
-

You have a computer that runs Windows 10 and contains a user named User1.

You need to ensure that User1 can add a third-party driver package for a printer to the driver store of the computer. The solution must use the principle of the least privilege.

To which local group should you add User1, and what should User1 run? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
Device owner group doesn't have permissions to user add-printerdriver (requires admin)

The correct answer is
Administrators / pnputil.exe

pnputil.exe is used exactly to add drivers to the driver store

Did a bit of research on this and tested on virtual machine. The first answer is absolutely "Administrator". BUT, the second answer could be either pnputil or Add-PrinterDriver. When installing a driver, it is added to the driver store on Windows 10. The Add-PrintDriver cmdlet does result in the driver being added and installed, however the pnputil does add a driver directly to the store without the install phase (unless you specifi /install). 

The tricky part comes in how these two methods function. The question asked what we should use to include the driver in the driver store, not install the driver. The answer will depend upon the circumstance, but without any additional info or requirements, the best answer seems to be pnputil, which is general purpose in adding drivers to the driver store. 

So, answer is: 
Administrator/pnputil

Group needs to be administrators and not Device Owners - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/identity/ad-ds/manage/understand-security-groups#device-owners

Run is pnputil as this is adding drivers to the driver store and not installing a printer - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/drivers/devtest/pnputil
